results.title: Fire making
results.creator_credit: Ian Dunlop and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “People of the Australian western desert (A)”.
A Pintubi boy makes a fire by friction of a spear-thrower on a log.

results.title: At Patantja clay pan
results.creator_credit: Ian Dunlop, John Martin-Jones and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “People of the Australian western desert (A)”.
Daily activities of two families camped near a clay pan holding water, showing desert food resources in a good season. The men hunt emus and the women collect mulga seed, ngaru fruit and grubs.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ian Dunlop, John Martin-Jones and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit

results.title: Arab traders of the Persian Gulf
results.creator_credit: Peggie Broadhead and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “People of Many Lands”.
A journey across the barren desert areas of the Gulf of Arabia with Arab traders. These are nomadic people living in primitive conditions. The film is one of a series which deals with a wide range of people, some of whom have retained primitive ways of life and have little contact with the outside world.

results.title: An Equal opportunity
results.creator_credit: Caroline Leaf, Robert Verrall, Wolf Koenig and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “People at Work”.
This open-ended drama is designed to trigger discussion on the subject of equal opportunities for women in the workplace and on the role of unions in securing those opportunities and working to eliminate discriminatory labour practices. Though set within a hospital and focussing on one of several staff women who are denied access to a pharmacy training program despite suitable qualifications, the underlying premises, conflicts and responses have implications that reach far beyond the hospital walls. Written by Gynne Basen, Clayton Bailey, Caroline Leaf; photographed by Wolf Koenig; edited by Judith Merritt; sound by John Martin, Bernie Bordeleau
results.creator_credit_for_label: Caroline Leaf, Robert Verrall, Wolf Koenig and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: A Right to refuse?
results.creator_credit: Clayton Bailey, Caroline Leaf, Wolf Koenig and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “People at Work”.
Dramatization of an industrial conflict. Workers should realise that they have the right to refuse to do jobs under dangerous or unhealthy conditions.

group_works.title: Steel (TEFC)
group_works.creator_credit: Gwynn Pritchard, Open University and BBC-TV

results.title: Steel (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Gwynn Pritchard, Open University and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “People and Work”.
Looks at the effect that modernisation of the work processes has had on the industrial relations and the experience of work and its consequences for the traditional skills of steel making. Shot entirely at the BSC Anchor Plant at Scunthorpe, the largest and most up-to-date steel works in Europe, it concentrates on the steel workers themselves. A case study for the students of the sociology of work.

results.title: 1949: Great leap: 1968: new release: 1970: half of the people
results.creator_credit: Anne Moir, Lisa Jones, Mark J. Davis, Angela Holdsworth, Jennifer Clayton, WGBH (Boston) and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “People’s century: 1900-1999”.
This tape contains episodes twenty to twenty two of the ‘People’s century 1900-1999’ series. “1949: great leap”; in 1949 Chairman Mao heads a resounding victory to Communism and the beginning of a Cultural Revolution intended to end the social divide between rich and poor. Throughout his reign Mao would gain support from the peasants and students, but at a high cost to human life through natural disasters such as famines, and persecution for those who did not follow party policy. Only death would stop the master plan. Narrated by Veronika Hyks. “1968: new release”; a generation of baby boomers brought up to “respect their elders” become teenagers and with the transition comes a new freedom as reflected in music, film and advertising at the time. Resistors to authoritarian rule became international heroes and youth across the world became involved in draft resistance to the Vietnam War. It was the start of a decade of student activism across Britain, Europe and America concerning issues such as the environment, women’s rights and gay liberation. Narrated by Sean Barrett. “1970: half the people”; women achieve a sense of purpose as they fill the roles of men who have left to fight, roles which do not seem destined to continue as the men return. A post-war generation of women take up the fight for equality and recall the battle for equal pay and opportunities and the sexual freedom obtained with the development of the new birth control pill. The situation would not be the same for women in third world countries such as Asia and Africa. Narrated by Sean Barrett.
results.title_for_label: 1949: Great leap: 1968: new release: 1970: half of the people
results.creator_credit_for_label: Anne Moir, Lisa Jones, Mark J. Davis, Angela Holdsworth, Jennifer Clayton, WGBH (Boston) and BBC
